nodes.label: Pythagorean identity for sine and cosine
nodes.title: The fundamental trigonometric identity stating that the square of cosine plus the square of sine of an angle equals one.

nodes.label: Sine rule for triangle side ratios
nodes.title: A formula relating the ratios of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles.

nodes.label: Cosine rule for triangle side lengths
nodes.title: A formula that relates the lengths of sides of a triangle to the cosine of one of its angles, useful for finding unknown sides or angles.

nodes.label: Cosine of angle difference formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the cosine of the difference between two angles in terms of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Cosine of angle sum formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the cosine of the sum of two angles in terms of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
nodes.title: An identity expressing the cosine of twice an angle as the difference of the squares of cosine and sine of the angle.

nodes.label: Sine of angle sum formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sine of the sum of two angles in terms of the sines and cosines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Sine of angle difference formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sine of the difference between two angles in terms of the sines and cosines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Tangent of angle sum formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the tangent of the sum of two angles in terms of the tangents of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Tangent of angle difference formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the tangent of the difference between two angles in terms of the tangents of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for sine (sin 2A)
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sine of twice an angle as twice the product of sine and cosine of the angle.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for tangent (tan 2A)
nodes.title: An identity expressing the tangent of twice an angle in terms of the tangent of the angle.

nodes.label: Cosine squared in terms of cosine double angle
nodes.title: An identity expressing the square of cosine of an angle as half the sum of one and the cosine of twice the angle.

nodes.label: Sine squared in terms of cosine double angle
nodes.title: An identity expressing the square of sine of an angle as half the difference of one and the cosine of twice the angle.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of cosines of two angles as the sum of cosines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of sine of one angle and cosine of another as the sum of sines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of sines of two angles as the difference of cosines of their difference and sum.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of cosine of one angle and sine of another as the difference of sines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for cos A + cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sum of cosines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for cos A – cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the difference of cosines of two angles as negative twice the product of sines of half their sum and half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for sin A + sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sum of sines of two angles as twice the product of sines of half their sum and cosines of half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for sin A – sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the difference of sines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and sines of half their difference.

nodes.label: circle drawing with given radius

nodes.label: use of trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles

nodes.title: Understanding that equations of the form ax + by + c = 0 represent straight lines in the coordinate plane.

nodes.title: Understanding the equation x² + y² + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 as representing a circle with center (-g, -f) and radius r = √(g² + f² - c).

nodes.label: perpendicular distance from a point to a line
nodes.title: Calculating the shortest distance between a given point and a line in the plane using coordinate geometry.

nodes.label: angle between two lines
nodes.title: Determining the measure of the angle formed where two lines intersect using their slopes.

nodes.label: internal division of a line segment in ratio m:n

nodes.title: Applying the Pythagorean theorem specifically to two-dimensional geometric problems involving right-angled triangles.

nodes.label: definition of sine and cosine for all angle values
nodes.title: Extending the definitions of sine and cosine functions beyond acute angles to all real values of θ, including negative and greater than 360° angles.

nodes.label: definition of tangent function
nodes.title: Defining the tangent function as the ratio of sine to cosine for any angle θ where cosine is not zero.

nodes.title: Using trigonometry and circle formulas to find the area of a sector defined by a central angle in a circle.

nodes.label: irrational numbers

nodes.label: complex numbers
nodes.title: Numbers consisting of a real part and an imaginary part, expressed in the form a + bi where i is the imaginary unit.

nodes.label: rules of indices: product rule
nodes.title: For the same base, multiplying powers adds their exponents: a^p × a^q = a^(p+q).

nodes.label: rules of indices: quotient rule
nodes.title: For the same base, dividing powers subtracts their exponents: a^p / a^q = a^(p−q).

nodes.label: rules of indices: zero exponent rule
nodes.title: Any non-zero base raised to the zero power equals one: a^0 = 1.

nodes.label: rules of indices: power of a power
nodes.title: Raising a power to another power multiplies the exponents: (a^p)^q = a^(pq).

nodes.label: rules of indices: negative exponents
nodes.title: A negative exponent represents the reciprocal of the positive exponent: a^(−p) = 1 / a^p.

nodes.label: rules of indices: product to a power
nodes.title: A product raised to a power equals the product of each factor raised to that power: (ab)^p = a^p b^p.

nodes.label: rules of indices: quotient to a power
nodes.title: A quotient raised to a power equals the quotient of each term raised to that power: (a/b)^p = a^p / b^p.

nodes.label: logarithm product rule
nodes.title: The logarithm of a product is the sum of the logarithms: log_a(xy) = log_a x + log_a y.

nodes.label: logarithm quotient rule
nodes.title: The logarithm of a quotient is the difference of the logarithms: log_a(x/y) = log_a x − log_a y.

nodes.label: logarithm power rule
nodes.title: The logarithm of a power is the exponent times the logarithm: log_a(x^q) = q log_a x.

nodes.label: logarithm of base and one
nodes.title: log_a a = 1 and log_a 1 = 0 for any valid base a.

nodes.label: change of base formula for logarithms
nodes.title: Expressing logarithms in terms of logs with a different base: log_a x = log_b x / log_b a.

nodes.title: Calculating the decrease in value of an asset by applying a fixed percentage reduction each period.

nodes.label: costing including materials, labour, and wastage
nodes.title: Calculating total costs by adding costs of materials, labour, and allowances for wastage.

nodes.label: metric and imperial unit conversions
nodes.title: Converting measurements between metric and imperial units using given conversion factors.

nodes.label: present value calculations for loans and investments
nodes.title: Determining the current worth of future sums of money or streams of cash flows given a specified rate of return.

nodes.label: real numbers (R)
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: real numbers (R)

nodes.label: Natural numbers
nodes.title: The set of whole positive numbers starting from 1 and increasing by 1 indefinitely.

nodes.label: Integers
nodes.title: The set of whole numbers including positive numbers, negative numbers, and zero.

nodes.label: Rational numbers as fractions
nodes.title: Numbers that can be expressed as a ratio of two integers, where the denominator is not zero.

nodes.label: Rational numbers as terminating or repeating decimals
nodes.title: Decimals that either terminate or repeat periodically, representing rational numbers.

nodes.label: Surds
nodes.title: Irrational numbers expressed in root form that cannot be simplified to remove the root.

nodes.label: Famous irrational numbers
nodes.title: Notable irrational numbers such as π (pi) and Euler's number e, which have important mathematical properties.

nodes.label: Simplifying surds by factorization
nodes.title: Expressing a surd as a product of a perfect square and another surd to simplify its form.

nodes.label: Constructing line segments of irrational length
nodes.title: Using geometric methods such as Pythagoras' theorem to construct line segments with lengths equal to irrational numbers like √2.

nodes.label: Imaginary numbers as square roots of negative numbers
nodes.title: Numbers expressed as multiples of i, where i is defined as the square root of -1.

nodes.label: Definition and properties of the imaginary unit i
nodes.title: The imaginary unit i satisfies i² = -1 and is used to define imaginary and complex numbers.

nodes.label: Real and imaginary parts of a complex number
nodes.title: The components a and b in a complex number a + bi, representing the real and imaginary parts respectively.

nodes.label: Addition of complex numbers in rectangular form
nodes.title: Adding complex numbers by separately adding their real parts and their imaginary parts.

nodes.label: Subtraction of complex numbers in rectangular form
nodes.title: Subtracting complex numbers by separately subtracting their real parts and their imaginary parts.

nodes.label: Multiplication of complex numbers in rectangular form
nodes.title: Multiplying complex numbers using distributive property and simplifying using i² = -1.

nodes.label: Complex conjugate of a complex number
nodes.title: For a complex number a + bi, its conjugate is a - bi, used to simplify division of complex numbers.

nodes.label: Division of complex numbers using conjugates
nodes.title: Dividing complex numbers by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator to rationalize it.

nodes.label: Multiplying a complex number by a real scalar
nodes.title: Scaling both the real and imaginary parts of a complex number by a real number, resulting in stretching or contraction in the Argand plane.

nodes.label: Reflection of a complex number through the origin
nodes.title: Multiplying a complex number by -1, which reflects it across the origin in the Argand diagram.

nodes.label: Translation of complex numbers in the Argand plane
nodes.title: Adding a fixed complex number to other complex numbers, resulting in a translation of their points in the complex plane.

nodes.label: Parallelogram law for addition of complex numbers
nodes.title: The geometric interpretation that the sum of two complex numbers corresponds to the diagonal of the parallelogram formed by their points and the origin.

nodes.label: Rotation of a complex number by multiplication by i
nodes.title: Multiplying a complex number by i rotates it 90 degrees anticlockwise about the origin in the Argand plane.

nodes.label: Rotation of a complex number by powers of i
nodes.title: Multiplying a complex number by iⁿ rotates it by 90° × n anticlockwise about the origin in the Argand plane.

nodes.label: Conjugate roots theorem for polynomials with real coefficients
nodes.title: If a polynomial with real coefficients has a complex root z, then its conjugate z̅ is also a root.

nodes.label: Modulus and argument of a complex number
nodes.title: The modulus is the distance from the origin; the argument is the angle the line from the origin to the point makes with the positive real axis.

nodes.label: Principal value of the argument
nodes.title: The unique value of the argument of a complex number restricted to the interval (-π, π].

nodes.label: Multiplication of complex numbers in polar form
nodes.title: The product of two complex numbers has modulus equal to the product of the moduli and argument equal to the sum of the arguments.

nodes.label: Division of complex numbers in polar form
nodes.title: The quotient of two complex numbers has modulus equal to the quotient of the moduli and argument equal to the difference of the arguments.

nodes.label: Proof of de Moivre’s theorem by mathematical induction
nodes.title: A stepwise proof showing the theorem holds for n=1, assuming true for n=k, then proving for n=k+1.

nodes.label: Application of de Moivre’s theorem to powers of complex numbers
nodes.title: Using the theorem to simplify expressions of complex numbers raised to integer powers in polar form.

nodes.label: Finding nth roots of complex numbers using polar form
nodes.title: Expressing the nth roots of a complex number by applying de Moivre’s theorem with fractional exponents and adding multiples of 2π to the argument.

nodes.label: General polar form of a complex number
nodes.title: Expressing a complex number as r[cos(θ + 2nπ) + i sin(θ + 2nπ)] to account for periodicity in trigonometric functions.

nodes.label: Scale factor in enlargements
nodes.title: The ratio by which lengths are multiplied to produce an enlargement of a figure.

nodes.label: Centre of enlargement
nodes.title: The fixed point about which a figure is enlarged or reduced.

nodes.label: Constructing an enlargement of a figure
nodes.title: Drawing lines from the centre of enlargement through each vertex and extending or contracting them by the scale factor to find the image vertices.

nodes.label: Enlargement with scale factor less than 1 (reduction)
nodes.title: An enlargement where the scale factor is between 0 and 1, resulting in a smaller image closer to the centre of enlargement.

nodes.label: Finding the centre of enlargement from an object and image
nodes.title: Locating the centre by joining corresponding points of the object and image and finding their intersection.

nodes.label: Effect of enlargement on area
nodes.title: The area of an enlarged figure is multiplied by the square of the scale factor.

nodes.label: Bisecting a line segment
nodes.title: Constructing the perpendicular bisector of a line segment to find its midpoint.

nodes.label: Bisecting an angle
nodes.title: Constructing a line that divides an angle into two equal parts using compass arcs.

nodes.label: Constructing an angle of 60 degrees
nodes.title: Using compass arcs to create an equilateral triangle and thereby construct a 60° angle.

nodes.label: Constructing a tangent to a circle at a given point
nodes.title: Drawing a line perpendicular to the radius at the point on the circle to form the tangent.

nodes.label: Constructing a parallelogram given side lengths and angle
nodes.title: Using a base, angle measurement, and compass arcs to construct a parallelogram with specified dimensions.

nodes.label: Constructing the circumcircle of a triangle
nodes.title: Finding the circumcentre by intersecting perpendicular bisectors of sides and drawing a circle through the vertices.

nodes.label: Constructing the incircle of a triangle
nodes.title: Finding the incentre by intersecting angle bisectors and drawing a circle tangent to all sides.

nodes.label: Constructing the centroid of a triangle
nodes.title: Finding the point of concurrency of the medians, which are lines from vertices to midpoints of opposite sides.

nodes.label: Constructing the orthocentre of a triangle
nodes.title: Finding the point of concurrency of the altitudes, which are perpendiculars from vertices to opposite sides.

nodes.label: Median of a triangle
nodes.title: A line segment joining a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.

nodes.label: Altitude of a triangle
nodes.title: A perpendicular segment from a vertex to the opposite side or its extension.

nodes.label: Pythagoras’ theorem applied to line construction
nodes.title: Using the relation a² + b² = c² to construct line segments of length √2 and other irrationals.

nodes.label: Antidifferentiation (integration) of power functions
nodes.title: Finding the original function given its derivative, typically by increasing the power by one and dividing by the new power.

nodes.label: Constant of integration
nodes.title: An arbitrary constant added to the antiderivative since differentiation of a constant is zero.

nodes.label: Integration of sine and cosine functions
nodes.title: Integrals of sin(ax) and cos(ax) are (-1/a)cos(ax) + c and (1/a)sin(ax) + c respectively.

nodes.label: Application of integration to displacement, velocity, and acceleration
nodes.title: Using integration to find velocity from acceleration and displacement from velocity in motion problems.

nodes.label: Definite integral as area under a curve
nodes.title: The definite integral of a function between two limits gives the net area between the curve and the x-axis over that interval.

nodes.label: Indefinite integral
nodes.title: An integral without specified limits representing a family of antiderivatives including a constant of integration.

nodes.label: Limits of integration
nodes.title: The lower and upper bounds a and b in a definite integral ∫_a^b f(x) dx.

nodes.label: Area between two curves
nodes.title: The area enclosed between two functions f(x) and g(x) over an interval is given by the integral of their difference.

nodes.label: Average value of a function over an interval
nodes.title: The height of a rectangle over the interval [a,b] with the same area as under the curve, calculated as (1/(b-a)) ∫_a^b f(x) dx.

nodes.label: Equation of tangent to a curve at a point
nodes.title: Using the derivative to find the slope at a point and applying point-slope form to find the tangent line equation.

nodes.label: Increasing and decreasing functions via first derivative
nodes.title: A function is increasing where its derivative is positive and decreasing where its derivative is negative.

nodes.label: Local maximum and minimum points
nodes.title: Stationary points where the function attains a local highest or lowest value respectively.

nodes.label: Second derivative test for turning points
nodes.title: Using the sign of the second derivative at a stationary point to determine if it is a local maximum (negative) or minimum (positive).

nodes.label: Point of inflection
nodes.title: A point on the curve where concavity changes and the second derivative is zero, often where the tangent crosses the curve.

nodes.label: Slope function (derived function) graph
nodes.title: The graph of the derivative of a function, showing the slope of the original function at each point.

nodes.label: Maximum and minimum problems using calculus
nodes.title: Using differentiation and second derivative test to find and classify maxima and minima in applied problems.

nodes.label: Related rates of change problems
nodes.title: Problems involving rates of change of related variables, solved using the chain rule of differentiation.

nodes.label: Chain rule for related rates
nodes.title: Differentiation rule stating that dy/dx = dy/du × du/dx for composite functions, used in related rates problems.

nodes.label: Geometric series
nodes.title: A sequence where each term is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant ratio.

nodes.label: Compound interest formula
nodes.title: Calculating accumulated amount with interest added to principal periodically, using A = P(1 + i)^t.

nodes.label: Annual Percentage Rate (APR) and Annual Equivalent Rate (AER)
nodes.title: APR is the true annual interest rate charged for borrowing; AER is the effective annual rate paid on investments.

nodes.label: Present value in compound interest
nodes.title: Calculating the current worth of a future sum of money discounted at a compound interest rate.

nodes.label: Straight line depreciation
nodes.title: Asset value decreases by a fixed amount each year over its useful life.

nodes.label: Reducing balance depreciation
nodes.title: Asset value decreases by a fixed percentage of its current value each year.

nodes.label: Instalment savings as geometric series
nodes.title: Accumulated value of regular payments with compound interest, represented as a sum of geometric series terms.

nodes.label: Pension present value calculation
nodes.title: Calculating the lump sum needed now to provide fixed periodic payments in the future, using geometric series.

nodes.label: Loan and mortgage repayment formula
nodes.title: Formula to calculate fixed periodic repayments on a loan or mortgage using present value of an annuity.

nodes.label: Properties of squares
nodes.title: Quadrilaterals with four equal sides, four right angles, and diagonals that bisect perpendicularly.

nodes.label: Properties of rectangles
nodes.title: Quadrilaterals with opposite sides equal, four right angles, and equal diagonals that bisect each other.

nodes.label: Properties of parallelograms
nodes.title: Quadrilaterals with opposite sides equal and parallel, opposite angles equal, and diagonals that bisect each other.

nodes.label: Area formulas for trapeziums
nodes.title: Area calculated as half the sum of the lengths of parallel sides multiplied by the height.

nodes.label: Regular polygons and interior angles
nodes.title: Polygons with equal sides and angles, with interior angles depending on the number of sides.

nodes.label: Length of arc of a circle
nodes.title: The length of a circular arc calculated as a fraction of the circumference based on the central angle in degrees or radians.

nodes.label: Area of a sector of a circle
nodes.title: Area of a sector calculated as a fraction of the circle's area based on the central angle in degrees or radians.

nodes.label: Volume and surface area of prisms
nodes.title: Volume is the product of the base area and length; surface area is sum of areas of all faces.

nodes.label: Volume and surface area of cylinders
nodes.title: Volume is πr²h; surface area includes areas of two circular bases and the curved surface.

nodes.label: Volume and surface area of cones
nodes.title: Volume is one-third of base area times height; surface area includes base and lateral surface area.

nodes.label: Volume and surface area of spheres and hemispheres
nodes.title: Volume of sphere is (4/3)πr³; hemisphere is half; surface area of sphere is 4πr²; hemisphere is 3πr².

nodes.label: Percentage error calculation
nodes.title: The relative difference between an estimated and true value expressed as a percentage of the true value.

nodes.label: Tolerance in measurement
nodes.title: The allowable deviation from a measured value, typically half the smallest unit of the measuring instrument.

nodes.label: Degrees of accuracy
nodes.title: The precision to which a measurement is recorded, affecting the possible range of the true value.

nodes.label: Trapezoidal rule for numerical integration
nodes.title: Approximating the area under a curve by dividing it into trapeziums and summing their areas.

nodes.label: Probability distributions for discrete random variables
nodes.title: A table or function assigning probabilities to each possible discrete outcome of a random variable.

nodes.label: Expected value of a discrete random variable
nodes.title: The weighted average of all possible values of a random variable, weighted by their probabilities.

nodes.label: Bernoulli trials
nodes.title: Repeated independent trials with two possible outcomes (success or failure) and constant probability of success.

nodes.label: Binomial distribution
nodes.title: Probability distribution giving the probability of k successes in n Bernoulli trials.

nodes.label: Multiplication rule for independent events
nodes.title: The probability of two independent events both occurring is the product of their individual probabilities.

nodes.label: Permutations and combinations in probability
nodes.title: Counting methods to determine the number of ways events can occur, used to calculate probabilities.

nodes.label: Probability of events occurring at least once
nodes.title: Calculating the probability that an event occurs one or more times by subtracting the probability of it never occurring from 1.

nodes.label: Ordered pairs and relations
nodes.title: Pairs of elements (x, y) representing inputs and outputs in a relation between two sets.

nodes.label: Domain and range of a relation
nodes.title: Domain is the set of all input values; range is the set of all output values in a relation.

nodes.label: Mapping diagrams for functions
nodes.title: Visual representation showing how each element of the domain maps to an element of the range.

nodes.label: Definition of a function
nodes.title: A relation where each input has exactly one unique output.

nodes.label: Codomain of a function
nodes.title: The set of possible output values specified for a function, which may be larger than the actual range.

nodes.label: Domain intervals and restricted domains
nodes.title: Limiting the domain of a function to intervals where it behaves as a function or to avoid undefined values.

nodes.label: Vertical line test
nodes.title: A graphical method to determine if a curve represents a function by checking if any vertical line intersects it more than once.

nodes.label: Non-commutativity of function composition
nodes.title: In general, composing functions in different orders yields different results, i.e., g ◦ f ≠ f ◦ g.

nodes.label: Injective (one-to-one) functions
nodes.title: Functions where each output corresponds to exactly one input; no two inputs map to the same output.

nodes.label: Horizontal line test for injectivity
nodes.title: A function is injective if every horizontal line intersects its graph at most once.

nodes.label: Surjective (onto) functions
nodes.title: Functions where every element of the codomain is an output of the function.

nodes.label: Horizontal line test for surjectivity
nodes.title: A function is surjective if every horizontal line intersects its graph at least once.

nodes.label: Bijective functions
nodes.title: Functions that are both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between domain and codomain.

nodes.label: Finding inverse functions algebraically
nodes.title: Solving the equation y = f(x) for x in terms of y and then interchanging variables to find f⁻¹(x).

nodes.label: Restricted domain for invertibility
nodes.title: Limiting the domain of a non-injective function to make it bijective and thus invertible.

nodes.label: Sketching graphs of linear functions
nodes.title: Plotting straight lines by finding intercepts and using slope.

nodes.label: Sketching graphs of quadratic functions
nodes.title: Plotting parabolas using intercepts, vertex (turning point), and axis of symmetry.

nodes.label: Completed square form of quadratic functions
nodes.title: Rewriting quadratics in the form y = a(x - p)² + q to identify vertex and graph shape.

nodes.label: Sketching graphs of cubic functions
nodes.title: Plotting cubic curves by finding intercepts and locating turning points.

nodes.label: Double root and its graphical significance
nodes.title: A root where the graph touches but does not cross the x-axis, corresponding to a turning point.

nodes.label: Graphs of exponential functions with base greater than 1
nodes.title: Increasing curves crossing y-axis at 1 and approaching x-axis as asymptote for negative x.

nodes.label: Graphs of exponential functions with base between 0 and 1
nodes.title: Decreasing curves crossing y-axis at 1 and approaching x-axis as asymptote for positive x.

nodes.label: Logarithmic functions as inverses of exponential functions
nodes.title: Functions defined as inverses of exponentials, with domain positive real numbers and range all real numbers.

nodes.label: Graph of natural logarithm function
nodes.title: Increasing curve with vertical asymptote at x=0, domain (0, ∞), range (-∞, ∞).

nodes.label: Transformations of function graphs: vertical translation
nodes.title: Adding or subtracting a constant to a function shifts its graph up or down.

nodes.label: Transformations of function graphs: horizontal translation
nodes.title: Replacing x by x ± a shifts the graph left or right by a units.

nodes.label: Reflection of function graphs about axes
nodes.title: Multiplying function by -1 reflects graph about x-axis; replacing x by -x reflects about y-axis.

nodes.label: Vertical stretching and compression of function graphs
nodes.title: Multiplying function by a constant scales the graph vertically, stretching if >1 and compressing if between 0 and 1.

nodes.label: Scatter diagrams for bivariate data
nodes.title: Graphs plotting pairs of data points to identify relationships between two variables.

nodes.label: Correlation between variables
nodes.title: Measure of the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

nodes.label: Positive, negative, and no correlation
nodes.title: Positive correlation means variables increase together; negative means one increases as the other decreases; no correlation means no linear relationship.

nodes.label: Causal relationship versus correlation
nodes.title: Causal relationship implies one variable causes change in another, while correlation only indicates association.

nodes.label: Correlation coefficient (r)
nodes.title: A numerical measure between -1 and 1 indicating the strength and direction of a linear relationship.

nodes.label: Product-moment correlation coefficient calculation
nodes.title: A method to compute the correlation coefficient based on sums of products of paired data deviations.

nodes.label: Line of best fit
nodes.title: A straight line that best represents the trend of data points in a scatter diagram, minimizing distances from points to the line.

nodes.label: Equation of line of best fit
nodes.title: Linear equation y = A + Bx representing the line of best fit, where B is slope and A is y-intercept.

nodes.label: Empirical Rule for normal distribution
nodes.title: Approximately 68%, 95%, and 99.7% of data lie within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of the mean respectively.

nodes.label: Standard score (z-score)
nodes.title: The number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean, calculated as (x - μ)/σ.

nodes.label: Standard normal distribution (Z distribution)
nodes.title: A normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1 used for standardizing scores.

nodes.label: Using standard normal tables to find probabilities
nodes.title: Tables giving the area under the standard normal curve up to a given z-score, used to find probabilities.

nodes.label: Margin of error approximation for proportions
nodes.title: Approximate margin of error calculated as 1/√n for a 95% confidence level.

nodes.label: Standard error of sample proportion
nodes.title: Estimated standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion, calculated as sqrt(p(1-p)/n).

nodes.label: Standard error of the mean
nodes.title: The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean, calculated as population standard deviation divided by square root of sample size.

nodes.label: Confidence interval for population mean
nodes.title: Interval estimate for the population mean based on sample mean, standard error, and confidence level.

nodes.label: Hypothesis testing for population mean
nodes.title: Testing claims about a population mean using sample data, test statistics, and critical regions at a given significance level.

nodes.label: Test statistic for hypothesis testing of mean
nodes.title: Standardized value calculated as (sample mean - population mean) divided by standard error, used to decide on hypothesis rejection.

nodes.label: Critical region and critical values
nodes.title: Ranges of test statistic values where the null hypothesis is rejected, defined by significance level and critical values.

nodes.label: p-value in hypothesis testing
nodes.title: The probability of obtaining a test statistic as extreme as the observed one, used to assess evidence against the null hypothesis.

nodes.label: polynomial expression with positive integer powers
nodes.title: An algebraic expression consisting of terms with variables raised to positive integer powers, combined using addition or subtraction.

nodes.label: linear polynomial expression
nodes.title: A polynomial expression where the highest power of the variable is 1, representing a straight-line relationship.

nodes.label: quadratic polynomial expression
nodes.title: A polynomial expression where the highest power of the variable is 2, forming a parabola when graphed.

nodes.label: cubic polynomial expression
nodes.title: A polynomial expression where the highest power of the variable is 3, producing a cubic curve when graphed.

nodes.label: polynomial terms ordered by decreasing powers
nodes.title: Writing polynomial expressions with terms arranged from highest to lowest power of the variable.

nodes.label: polynomial terms ordered by increasing powers
nodes.title: Writing polynomial expressions with terms arranged from lowest to highest power of the variable.

nodes.label: coefficient of a polynomial term
nodes.title: The numerical factor multiplying the variable raised to a power in a polynomial term.

nodes.label: constant term in polynomial
nodes.title: The term in a polynomial expression that does not contain any variables.

nodes.label: addition and subtraction of polynomial expressions by combining like terms
nodes.title: Simplifying polynomial expressions by adding or subtracting terms with the same variable and power.

nodes.label: binomial expression
nodes.title: A polynomial expression consisting of exactly two terms.

nodes.label: trinomial expression
nodes.title: A polynomial expression consisting of exactly three terms.

nodes.label: multiplying polynomial expressions using distributive law (expanding)
nodes.title: Applying the distributive property to multiply each term in one polynomial by each term in another, resulting in an expanded polynomial.

nodes.label: perfect square polynomial
nodes.title: A polynomial that is the square of a binomial, expressed as (x ± a)^2.

nodes.label: expansion of perfect square binomial (x + a)^2
nodes.title: The expansion of (x + a)^2 into x^2 + 2ax + a^2.

nodes.label: expansion of perfect square binomial (x - a)^2
nodes.title: The expansion of (x - a)^2 into x^2 - 2ax + a^2.

nodes.label: difference of two squares
nodes.title: The identity expressing (x - a)(x + a) as x^2 - a^2.

nodes.label: division of polynomial expressions by monomial factor
nodes.title: Simplifying polynomial quotients when the denominator divides each term of the numerator.

nodes.label: division of polynomial expressions by binomial factor
nodes.title: Simplifying polynomial quotients when the denominator is a factor of the numerator polynomial.

nodes.label: polynomial long division
nodes.title: A method for dividing polynomials where terms are divided stepwise, subtracting multiples of the divisor until the remainder is found.

nodes.label: polynomial factorisation by division
nodes.title: Expressing a polynomial as a product of a divisor and a quotient polynomial after division.

nodes.label: polynomial function notation and evaluation
nodes.title: Representing a polynomial as a function f(x) and evaluating it by substituting values for x.

nodes.label: independent and dependent variables in polynomial functions
nodes.title: The independent variable is the input value (x), and the dependent variable is the output (f(x)) determined by the polynomial function.

nodes.label: polynomial functions with multiple independent variables
nodes.title: Polynomial functions that depend on two or more variables, with degree determined by the highest power among variables.

nodes.label: highest common factor (HCF) by inspection
nodes.title: Identifying the greatest common factor shared by all terms in an algebraic expression by visual inspection.

nodes.label: factorisation by grouping
nodes.title: Rearranging terms in a polynomial to group and factor common factors from each group.

nodes.label: factorisation using difference of two squares
nodes.title: Factoring expressions of the form a^2 - b^2 into (a - b)(a + b).

nodes.label: factorising quadratic expressions by trial and error
nodes.title: Finding factors of quadratic expressions by testing factor pairs of the constant term to match the middle term coefficient.

nodes.label: factorising quadratic expressions using quadratic formula
nodes.title: Using the quadratic formula to find roots and express the quadratic as a product of linear factors.

nodes.label: factorising difference and sum of cubes
nodes.title: Expressing x^3 - y^3 as (x - y)(x^2 + xy + y^2) and x^3 + y^3 as (x + y)(x^2 - xy + y^2).

nodes.label: simplifying algebraic fractions by common denominator
nodes.title: Adding or subtracting algebraic fractions by rewriting them with a common denominator.

nodes.label: simplifying algebraic fractions by cancelling common factors
nodes.title: Reducing algebraic fractions by dividing numerator and denominator by their common factors.

nodes.label: multiplying algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Multiplying numerators and denominators separately to find the product of algebraic fractions.

nodes.label: dividing algebraic fractions by multiplying by reciprocal
nodes.title: Dividing fractions by multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.

nodes.label: binomial expansion for powers 2 to 5
nodes.title: Expanding (a - b)^n for n=2 to 5 using binomial coefficients and powers of a and b.

nodes.label: binomial coefficients and Pascal’s triangle
nodes.title: Coefficients in binomial expansions corresponding to entries in Pascal’s triangle, representing combinations.

nodes.label: binomial theorem general formula
nodes.title: Formula to expand (x - y)^n as sum of terms with binomial coefficients, powers of x and y.

nodes.label: algebraic identity
nodes.title: An equation true for all values of the variable(s), where coefficients of like powers are equal.

nodes.label: partial fraction decomposition using algebraic identities
nodes.title: Expressing a rational function as sum of simpler fractions using algebraic identities.

nodes.label: manipulating formulae to make a variable the subject
nodes.title: Rearranging an equation to express one variable explicitly in terms of others.

nodes.label: linear function pattern
nodes.title: A sequence where each term changes by a constant difference, represented by f(x) = mx + c.

nodes.label: first difference in linear sequences
nodes.title: The constant difference between consecutive terms in a linear sequence, equal to the slope m.

nodes.label: quadratic function pattern
nodes.title: A sequence where the second difference between terms is constant, represented by f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c.

nodes.label: second difference in quadratic sequences
nodes.title: The constant difference of the first differences in a quadratic sequence, equal to 2a.

nodes.label: solving linear equations
nodes.title: Finding the value(s) of the variable that satisfy an equation of the form y = ax + b.

nodes.label: roots of an equation
nodes.title: Values of the variable that make the equation equal to zero, often where the graph crosses the x-axis.

nodes.label: solving simultaneous linear equations by substitution
nodes.title: Solving two linear equations by expressing one variable in terms of the other and substituting into the second equation.

nodes.label: solving simultaneous linear equations by elimination
nodes.title: Solving two linear equations by adding or subtracting them to eliminate one variable.

nodes.label: solving simultaneous linear equations graphically
nodes.title: Finding the point of intersection of two lines representing linear equations on a graph.

nodes.label: solving simultaneous equations with three variables
nodes.title: Reducing three equations with three variables to two equations with two variables by elimination, then solving sequentially.

nodes.label: quadratic equation
nodes.title: An equation of the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0 where a ≠ 0, representing a parabola.

nodes.label: solving quadratic equations by factorisation
nodes.title: Finding roots by expressing the quadratic as a product of linear factors equal to zero.

nodes.label: solving quadratic equations using quadratic formula
nodes.title: Using the formula x = [-b ± sqrt(b^2 - 4ac)]/(2a) to find roots of any quadratic equation.

nodes.label: solving quadratic equations graphically
nodes.title: Finding approximate roots by identifying x-intercepts of the parabola y = ax^2 + bx + c.

nodes.label: solving quadratic equations by substitution
nodes.title: Transforming equations by substituting variables to reduce to quadratic form for easier solving.

nodes.label: discriminant of quadratic equation
nodes.title: The expression b^2 - 4ac determining the nature of roots of ax^2 + bx + c = 0.

nodes.label: nature of quadratic roots: real distinct
nodes.title: Quadratic roots are two distinct real numbers when discriminant > 0.

nodes.label: nature of quadratic roots: real equal
nodes.title: Quadratic roots are real and equal when discriminant = 0.

nodes.label: nature of quadratic roots: complex
nodes.title: Quadratic roots are complex conjugates when discriminant < 0.

nodes.label: rational roots of quadratic equations
nodes.title: Quadratic roots are rational when the discriminant is a perfect square.

nodes.label: forming quadratic equations from roots
nodes.title: Constructing a quadratic equation given its roots r1 and r2 as (x - r1)(x - r2) = 0.

nodes.label: centroid of a triangle

nodes.label: circumcentre of a triangle

nodes.label: orthocentre of a triangle
nodes.title: Point of concurrency of altitudes (perpendiculars from vertices to opposite sides).

nodes.label: perpendicular distance from point to line
nodes.title: Shortest distance from point (x1, y1) to line ax + by + c = 0 given by |ax1 + by1 + c| / sqrt(a^2 + b^2).

nodes.title: Angle θ between lines with slopes m1 and m2 found by tan θ = |(m1 - m2)/(1 + m1 m2)|.

nodes.label: permutation of n objects
nodes.title: Number of ordered arrangements of n distinct objects, equal to n!.

nodes.label: permutation of n objects taken r at a time
nodes.title: Number of ordered arrangements of r objects selected from n distinct objects, nPr = n! / (n - r)!.

nodes.label: combination of n objects taken r at a time
nodes.title: Number of unordered selections of r objects from n distinct objects, nCr = n! / (r! (n - r)!).

nodes.label: fundamental principle of counting
nodes.title: If one task can be done in m ways and another in n ways, total ways to do both is m × n.

nodes.label: experimental probability (relative frequency)
nodes.title: Probability estimated by ratio of successful outcomes to total trials in an experiment.

nodes.label: expected frequency
nodes.title: Expected number of occurrences of an event in a number of trials, calculated as probability × number of trials.

nodes.label: mutually exclusive events
nodes.title: Events that cannot occur simultaneously; probability of A or B is P(A) + P(B).

nodes.label: addition rule for non-mutually exclusive events
nodes.title: Probability of A or B is P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B) when events can occur together.

nodes.label: sample space
nodes.title: The set of all possible outcomes of an experiment.

nodes.label: multiplication law for independent events
nodes.title: Probability of both independent events A and B occurring is P(A) × P(B).

nodes.label: conditional probability
nodes.title: Probability of event A given event B has occurred, denoted P(A|B), calculated as P(A and B)/P(B).

nodes.label: circle equation with center at origin

nodes.label: circle equation with center at (h, k)
nodes.title: Equation (x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2 representing a circle centered at (h,k) with radius r.

nodes.label: general form of circle equation
nodes.title: Equation x^2 + y^2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 representing a circle with center (-g, -f) and radius sqrt(g^2 + f^2 - c).

nodes.label: tangent to a circle at a point
nodes.title: A line that touches the circle at exactly one point and is perpendicular to the radius at that point.

nodes.label: length of tangent from external point to circle
nodes.title: Length of tangent segment from a point outside the circle to the point of contact on the circle.

nodes.label: points of intersection of line and circle
nodes.title: Solutions to simultaneous equations of a line and circle representing intersection points; one solution means tangent.

nodes.label: common chord of two circles

nodes.label: circle touching coordinate axes
nodes.title: Circle touching x-axis or y-axis has radius equal to absolute value of corresponding coordinate of center.

nodes.label: average rate of change of a function

nodes.label: limit of a function as x approaches a value
nodes.title: The value that f(x) approaches as x approaches a specified point.

nodes.label: continuity of a function at a point

nodes.label: derivative of a constant

nodes.label: product rule for differentiation

nodes.title: Properties of distance including non-negativity, symmetry, additivity when a point lies between two others, and existence of a unique point at a given distance along a ray.

nodes.label: midpoint of a segment
nodes.title: The point on a segment that divides it into two equal parts.

nodes.label: convex set
nodes.title: A subset of the plane containing every segment connecting any two of its points.

nodes.label: angle and its components
nodes.title: An angle consists of a vertex point and two rays (arms) starting at the vertex, enclosing a region called the inside of the angle.

nodes.label: null angle
nodes.title: An angle whose arms coincide and whose inside is empty, measuring 0 degrees.

nodes.label: ordinary angle
nodes.title: An angle with arms not on the same line and whose inside is a convex set, measuring between 0 and 180 degrees.

nodes.label: straight angle
nodes.title: An angle whose arms are opposite rays forming a straight line, measuring exactly 180 degrees.

nodes.label: reflex angle
nodes.title: An angle with arms not on the same line and whose inside is not convex, measuring more than 180 degrees but less than 360 degrees.

nodes.label: full angle
nodes.title: An angle whose arms coincide and whose inside is the entire plane except the arms, measuring 360 degrees.

nodes.label: notation for angles using points and Greek letters
nodes.title: Angles are denoted by three points with the vertex in the middle (e.g. \BAC), or by lowercase Greek letters when unnamed.

nodes.label: degree measure of an angle
nodes.title: The numerical measure of an angle in degrees, ranging from 0° to 360°, with ordinary angles less than 180°.

nodes.label: protractor axiom
nodes.title: Axiomatic properties of angle measures including existence of unique rays forming given angles and additivity of angles inside another angle.

nodes.label: angle bisector
nodes.title: A ray from the vertex of an angle dividing it into two equal angles.

nodes.label: right angle
nodes.title: An angle measuring exactly 90 degrees.

nodes.label: acute angle
nodes.title: An angle measuring less than 90 degrees.

nodes.label: obtuse angle
nodes.title: An angle measuring more than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees.

nodes.label: supplementary angles
nodes.title: Two angles whose measures add up to 180 degrees.

nodes.label: perpendicular lines
nodes.title: Two lines intersecting to form a right angle (90 degrees).

nodes.label: vertically-opposite angles
nodes.title: Pairs of opposite angles formed when two lines intersect, which are equal in measure.

nodes.label: congruent triangles
nodes.title: Two triangles with all corresponding sides and angles equal.

nodes.label: triangle congruence criteria (SAS, ASA, SSS)
nodes.title: Conditions under which two triangles are congruent: Side-Angle-Side, Angle-Side-Angle, or Side-Side-Side equalities.

nodes.label: right-angled triangle
nodes.title: A triangle with one angle exactly 90 degrees; the side opposite this angle is the hypotenuse.

nodes.label: isosceles triangle
nodes.title: A triangle with two equal sides and consequently two equal opposite angles.

nodes.label: equilateral triangle
nodes.title: A triangle with all three sides equal and all angles equal to 60 degrees.

nodes.label: scalene triangle
nodes.title: A triangle with all sides of different lengths and all angles different.

nodes.label: parallel lines
nodes.title: Two lines that are either identical or have no points in common, never intersecting.

nodes.label: transversal line
nodes.title: A line that intersects two or more other lines at distinct points.

nodes.label: alternate interior angles
nodes.title: Pairs of angles on opposite sides of a transversal but inside the two lines, which are equal if the lines are parallel.

nodes.label: corresponding angles
nodes.title: Pairs of angles in matching corners when a transversal crosses two lines, equal if the lines are parallel.

nodes.label: angle sum of triangle
nodes.title: The sum of the three interior angles of any triangle is exactly 180 degrees.

nodes.label: exterior angle of a triangle
nodes.title: An angle formed outside a triangle when one side is extended; equal to the sum of the two interior opposite angles.

nodes.label: angle-side inequality in triangles
nodes.title: The angle opposite the longer side of a triangle is larger, and conversely, larger angles face longer sides.

nodes.label: triangle inequality theorem
nodes.title: The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle is greater than the length of the third side.

nodes.label: perpendicular bisector of a segment
nodes.title: A line perpendicular to a segment at its midpoint, dividing it into two equal parts.

nodes.label: polygon
nodes.title: A closed chain of line segments joined end-to-end without crossing, forming a plane figure with vertices and sides.

nodes.label: quadrilateral
nodes.title: A polygon with exactly four vertices and four sides.

nodes.label: opposite sides and opposite angles of a quadrilateral
nodes.title: Pairs of sides or angles in a quadrilateral that do not share a vertex or side.

nodes.label: rectangle
nodes.title: A quadrilateral with four right angles.

nodes.label: rhombus
nodes.title: A quadrilateral with all four sides equal in length.

nodes.label: square
nodes.title: A quadrilateral that is both a rectangle and a rhombus, having four equal sides and four right angles.

nodes.label: regular polygon
nodes.title: A polygon with all sides and all interior angles equal.

nodes.label: parallelogram
nodes.title: A quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides parallel.

nodes.label: diagonal divides parallelogram into congruent triangles
nodes.title: A diagonal of a parallelogram splits it into two triangles that are congruent.

nodes.label: ratio division of a segment
nodes.title: A point divides a segment into two parts whose lengths are in a given ratio s:t.

nodes.label: similar triangles
nodes.title: Triangles with corresponding angles equal and corresponding sides proportional.

nodes.label: properties of parallel lines cutting segments proportionally
nodes.title: If three parallel lines cut equal segments on one transversal, they cut equal segments on any other transversal.

nodes.label: triangle similarity criteria (AA, SAS proportionality, SSS proportionality)
nodes.title: Conditions under which two triangles are similar: two equal angles, or two sides proportional with included angle equal, or all sides proportional.

nodes.label: Pythagorean theorem
nodes.title: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

nodes.label: converse of Pythagorean theorem
nodes.title: If the square of one side of a triangle equals the sum of the squares of the other two, then the triangle has a right angle opposite that side.

nodes.label: RHS triangle congruence criterion
nodes.title: Two right-angled triangles are congruent if their hypotenuses and one other side are equal.

nodes.label: perpendicular bisector equidistance property
nodes.title: Any point on the perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from the segment's endpoints.

nodes.label: equal length of perpendiculars from angle bisector
nodes.title: Perpendiculars dropped from any point on an angle bisector to the arms of the angle have equal length.

nodes.label: area of a triangle
nodes.title: Half the product of a chosen base length and its corresponding height.

nodes.label: additivity of area for triangles
nodes.title: The area of a triangle divided by a segment is the sum of the areas of the two smaller triangles formed.

nodes.label: area of rectangle
nodes.title: The product of the lengths of its two adjacent sides.

nodes.label: area of parallelogram
nodes.title: The product of the base length and the corresponding height.

nodes.label: circle and its components
nodes.title: A set of points equidistant (radius) from a fixed point (center), including chords, diameter (twice radius), arcs, sectors, circumference, and disc (interior).

nodes.label: angle at center and angle at circumference
nodes.title: The angle at the center standing on an arc is twice the angle at any point on the circumference standing on the same arc.

nodes.label: angles standing on the same arc are equal
nodes.title: All angles at points on the circle standing on the same arc are equal in measure.

nodes.label: angle in a semicircle
nodes.title: An angle standing on a diameter arc is a right angle (90 degrees).

nodes.label: cyclic quadrilateral
nodes.title: A quadrilateral whose vertices all lie on a single circle.

nodes.label: opposite angles of cyclic quadrilateral sum to 180 degrees
nodes.title: In a cyclic quadrilateral, each pair of opposite angles adds up to 180 degrees.

nodes.label: line tangent to a circle
nodes.title: A line that touches a circle at exactly one point, called the point of contact.

nodes.label: tangent perpendicular to radius
nodes.title: A tangent line to a circle is perpendicular to the radius drawn to the point of contact.

nodes.label: perpendicular from center to chord bisects the chord
nodes.title: The perpendicular line from the center of a circle to a chord divides the chord into two equal parts.

nodes.label: perpendicular bisector of chord passes through center
nodes.title: The perpendicular bisector of any chord passes through the center of the circle.

nodes.label: circumcircle of a triangle
nodes.title: The unique circle passing through all three vertices of a triangle; its center is the circumcentre and radius is the circumradius.

nodes.label: incircle of a triangle
nodes.title: The circle inside a triangle tangent to all three sides; its center is the incentre and radius is the inradius.

nodes.label: geometric constructions with compass and straight-edge
nodes.title: Procedures to construct geometric figures such as angle bisectors, perpendicular bisectors, perpendicular and parallel lines, division of segments into equal parts, triangles with given data, and circle centers using only compass and straight-edge.

nodes.label: division of a segment into equal parts without measurement
nodes.title: Constructing points dividing a segment into 2, 3, or any number of equal parts using geometric methods without measuring lengths.

nodes.label: construction of triangle given three sides (SSS)
nodes.title: Constructing a triangle when the lengths of all three sides are known.

nodes.label: construction of triangle given SAS data
nodes.title: Constructing a triangle when two sides and the included angle are given.

nodes.label: construction of triangle given ASA data
nodes.title: Constructing a triangle when two angles and the included side are given.

nodes.label: construction of right-angled triangle given hypotenuse and one side
nodes.title: Constructing a right triangle when the hypotenuse and one other side length are known.

nodes.label: construction of right-angled triangle given one side and one acute angle
nodes.title: Constructing a right triangle when one side length and one acute angle are known.

nodes.label: construction of circumcentre and circumcircle
nodes.title: Using compass and straight-edge to find the circumcentre of a triangle and draw its circumcircle.

nodes.label: construction of incentre and incircle
nodes.title: Using compass and straight-edge to find the incentre of a triangle and draw its incircle.

nodes.label: construction of tangent to a circle at a given point
nodes.title: Constructing the line tangent to a circle at a specified point on the circle using compass and straight-edge.

nodes.label: construction of centroid of a triangle
nodes.title: Constructing the point where the medians of a triangle intersect using compass and straight-edge.

nodes.label: construction of orthocentre of a triangle
nodes.title: Constructing the point where the altitudes of a triangle intersect using compass and straight-edge.

nodes.label: polynomial expressions
nodes.title: Algebraic expressions consisting of variables and coefficients combined using addition, subtraction, and multiplication with non-negative integer exponents.

nodes.label: polynomial functions introduction
nodes.title: Functions defined by polynomial expressions where the output depends on the input variable raised to whole number powers.

nodes.label: factorising algebraic expressions
nodes.title: The process of rewriting algebraic expressions as a product of simpler expressions or factors.

nodes.label: simplifying algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Reducing algebraic fractions to their simplest form by factoring numerators and denominators and cancelling common factors.

nodes.label: binomial expansions
nodes.title: Expanding powers of binomials into sums involving terms with coefficients given by binomial coefficients.

nodes.label: algebraic identities
nodes.title: Equations involving algebraic expressions that hold true for all values of the variables involved.

nodes.label: manipulating formulae

nodes.label: algebraic patterns introduction

nodes.label: solving simultaneous linear equations
nodes.title: Finding values of variables that satisfy two or more linear equations at the same time.

nodes.label: quadratic equations

nodes.title: Classification of the roots of a quadratic equation as real and distinct, real and equal, or complex based on the discriminant.

nodes.title: Ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle defined as sine, cosine, and tangent of an angle.

nodes.label: sine rule for area of a triangle
nodes.title: Formula using sine of an angle and two sides of a triangle to calculate its area.

nodes.label: problems in three dimensions using trigonometry
nodes.title: Application of trigonometric principles to solve spatial problems involving three-dimensional figures.

nodes.label: graphs of trigonometric functions
nodes.title: Plotting and analysis of sine, cosine, and tangent functions over intervals, showing periodicity and amplitude.

nodes.label: related trigonometric graphs
nodes.title: Graphs of trigonometric functions derived from basic functions by transformations such as shifts, stretches, and reflections.

nodes.label: general solutions of trigonometric equations
nodes.title: Finding all possible solutions to trigonometric equations over specified domains, including periodic repetitions.

nodes.label: revision of coordinate geometry formulae
nodes.title: Review of key formulas used in coordinate geometry such as distance, midpoint, and gradient formulas.

nodes.label: area of a triangle using coordinate geometry
nodes.title: Calculating the area of a triangle given coordinates of its vertices using determinant or coordinate formulas.

nodes.label: equation of a line
nodes.title: Mathematical expressions representing straight lines in coordinate geometry, including forms like slope-intercept and point-slope.

nodes.label: dividing a line segment in a given ratio
nodes.title: Finding coordinates of a point that divides a line segment between two points in a specified ratio.

nodes.label: concurrencies of a triangle
nodes.title: Points where three or more lines associated with a triangle intersect, such as centroid, orthocenter, and circumcenter.

nodes.label: using linear relationships to solve problems
nodes.title: Applying knowledge of linear equations and their graphs to solve contextual mathematical problems.

nodes.label: permutations
nodes.title: Counting the number of ways to arrange a set of objects where order matters.

nodes.label: combinations
nodes.title: Counting the number of ways to select objects from a set where order does not matter.

nodes.title: Basic concepts of probability including sample spaces, events, and calculating simple probabilities.

nodes.title: Estimating probability based on the ratio of the number of times an event occurs to the total number of trials.

nodes.label: angles in triangles and parallelograms
nodes.title: Properties and measures of angles within triangles and parallelograms, including angle sums and relationships.

nodes.label: theorems involving triangles and parallelograms
nodes.title: Geometric theorems related to properties of triangles and parallelograms, such as congruence and parallelism.

nodes.label: ratio theorems in geometry
nodes.title: Theorems that relate ratios of lengths within geometric figures, often used in similarity and proportionality problems.

nodes.label: circle theorems
nodes.title: Properties and theorems related to angles, chords, tangents, and arcs in circles.

nodes.label: average rate of change
nodes.title: The change in the value of a function divided by the change in the independent variable over an interval.

nodes.label: limits and continuity
nodes.title: Concepts describing the behavior of functions as inputs approach a point and whether the function is continuous at that point.

nodes.label: differentiating from first principles
nodes.title: Finding the derivative of a function using the definition of the derivative as a limit of difference quotients.

nodes.label: differentiation by rule
nodes.title: Applying standard rules such as power, product, quotient, and chain rules to find derivatives of functions.

nodes.label: product, quotient and chain rules
nodes.title: Rules for differentiating products, quotients, and compositions of functions respectively.

nodes.label: second derivatives
nodes.title: The derivative of the derivative of a function, representing the rate of change of the rate of change.

nodes.label: derivatives of trigonometric functions
nodes.title: Rules for differentiating sine, cosine, tangent, and other trigonometric functions.

nodes.label: differentiating logarithmic functions
nodes.title: Finding derivatives of logarithmic functions including natural and other bases.

nodes.label: trigonometric identities
nodes.title: Equations involving trigonometric functions that are true for all values of the variable, such as Pythagorean identities.

nodes.label: compound angle formulae
nodes.title: Formulas expressing trigonometric functions of sums or differences of angles in terms of functions of individual angles.

nodes.label: double-angle formulae
nodes.title: Formulas for trigonometric functions of twice an angle expressed in terms of functions of the original angle.

nodes.label: sum, difference and product formulae for trigonometry
nodes.title: Formulas relating sums, differences, and products of trigonometric functions to other trigonometric expressions.

nodes.label: inverse trigonometric functions
nodes.title: Functions that give the angle corresponding to a given trigonometric ratio, such as arcsin, arccos, and arctan.

nodes.label: sequences
nodes.title: Ordered lists of numbers following a particular pattern or rule.

nodes.label: arithmetic series
nodes.title: The sum of the terms of an arithmetic sequence.

nodes.label: other sequences
nodes.title: Sequences that do not fit arithmetic or geometric patterns, including recursive or special sequences.

nodes.title: Further exploration and analysis of numeric patterns and their algebraic representations.

nodes.title: Classification of data into categories such as qualitative, quantitative, discrete, and continuous.

nodes.title: Methods and techniques for gathering data for statistical analysis.

nodes.label: populations and sampling
nodes.title: Concepts related to entire groups under study and subsets selected for analysis.

nodes.title: Statistical values that describe the central tendency of data, such as mean, median, and mode.

nodes.label: measures of variability
nodes.title: Statistics that describe the spread or dispersion of data, including range, variance, and standard deviation.

nodes.label: stem and leaf diagrams (stemplots)
nodes.title: A graphical method for displaying quantitative data to show distribution while retaining original data values.

nodes.label: histograms
nodes.title: Bar graphs representing the frequency distribution of continuous data grouped into intervals.

nodes.label: shape of a distribution
nodes.title: Description of the form of a data distribution, including symmetry, skewness, and modality.

nodes.label: equation of a circle with center at origin
nodes.title: The standard form equation x^2 + y^2 = r^2 representing a circle centered at (0,0) with radius r.

nodes.label: equations of circles with centers not at origin
nodes.title: General form equations of circles centered at any point (h,k), expressed as (x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2.

nodes.label: finding the equation of a circle
nodes.title: Determining the algebraic equation of a circle given its center and radius or other geometric information.

nodes.label: tangents to a circle
nodes.title: Lines that touch a circle at exactly one point and their equations and properties.

nodes.label: lines and circles: common chord
nodes.title: The line segment formed by the intersection of two circles or a circle and a line intersecting in two points.

nodes.label: touching circles: chords and circles
nodes.title: Properties and relationships involving circles that touch each other and the chords formed.

nodes.label: circles touching the x-axis or y-axis
nodes.title: Circles that are tangent to coordinate axes and the conditions for their equations.

nodes.label: quadratic inequalities
nodes.title: Inequalities involving quadratic expressions, solved by analyzing the sign of the quadratic function.

nodes.label: rational inequalities
nodes.title: Inequalities involving rational expressions, solved by considering domain restrictions and sign analysis.

nodes.label: modulus (absolute value)
nodes.title: The non-negative value of a number representing its distance from zero on the number line.

nodes.label: mathematical proof
nodes.title: Logical arguments establishing the truth of mathematical statements using deductive reasoning.

nodes.label: proofs of abstract inequalities
nodes.title: Demonstrations of inequalities involving algebraic expressions or functions using formal proof techniques.

nodes.label: indices (exponents)
nodes.title: Rules and properties governing powers and exponents in algebraic expressions.

nodes.label: exponential equations
nodes.title: Equations where variables appear as exponents, solved using logarithms or exponent rules.

nodes.title: The curve representing the logarithmic function with base a, showing its domain, range, and key features.

nodes.title: Applying properties of exponential and logarithmic functions to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

nodes.label: proofs by induction
nodes.title: A method of mathematical proof used to establish the truth of an infinite sequence of statements.

nodes.label: Listing all possible outcomes of an experiment
nodes.title: Systematically enumerating every possible result that can occur from a random experiment.

nodes.label: Informal to formal probability descriptions
nodes.title: Progression from intuitive, everyday language about likelihood to precise numerical probability values between 0 and 1.

nodes.label: Experimental probability estimation
nodes.title: Estimating the probability of an event by conducting trials and calculating the relative frequency of the event occurring.

nodes.label: Theoretical probability calculation for equally likely outcomes
nodes.title: Calculating probability as the ratio of favorable outcomes to total equally likely outcomes in the sample space.

nodes.label: Constructing sample spaces for two independent events
nodes.title: Creating a set of all possible ordered pairs of outcomes from two independent random events.

nodes.label: Counting permutations of n distinct objects
nodes.title: Calculating the number of ways to arrange n distinct objects in order, equal to n! (n factorial).

nodes.label: Counting permutations of r objects from n distinct objects
nodes.title: Calculating the number of ordered arrangements of r objects selected from n distinct objects, given by nPr = n!/(n-r)!.

nodes.label: Counting combinations of r objects from n distinct objects
nodes.title: Calculating the number of ways to select r objects from n distinct objects without regard to order, given by the binomial coefficient nCr = n!/(r!(n-r)!).

nodes.label: Computing binomial coefficients
nodes.title: Calculating coefficients representing the number of combinations of r objects from n, often denoted as nCr or 'n choose r'.

nodes.label: Using set theory to describe experiments and outcomes
nodes.title: Applying concepts of sets, subsets, unions, intersections, and complements to represent events and sample spaces.

nodes.label: Basic probability rules with Venn diagrams
nodes.title: Using Venn diagrams to visualize and apply rules such as AND, OR, and mutually exclusive events.

nodes.label: Addition rule for probability
nodes.title: Calculating the probability of the union of two events as P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A ∩ B).

nodes.label: General multiplication rule for dependent events
nodes.title: Calculating the probability of the intersection of two events where one depends on the other as P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B | A).

nodes.label: Conditional probability and its asymmetry
nodes.title: Understanding that P(A | B) is generally not equal to P(B | A), reflecting the directionality in conditional probabilities.

nodes.label: Sampling with and without replacement
nodes.title: Distinguishing between selecting items where each selection is returned to the population (with replacement) or not (without replacement), affecting probabilities.

nodes.label: Probability of two independent events both occurring
nodes.title: Calculating the probability that both independent events happen by multiplying their individual probabilities.

nodes.title: Calculating the probability that exactly k successes occur in n independent Bernoulli trials using the binomial distribution formula.

nodes.label: Probability that the kth success occurs on the nth Bernoulli trial
nodes.title: Calculating the probability that the kth success happens exactly at the nth trial in a sequence of Bernoulli trials.

nodes.title: Employing computational methods to model repeated sampling and observe the distribution of sample statistics like the mean.

nodes.label: Reading probabilities from normal distribution tables
nodes.title: Using standard normal tables to find probabilities or percentiles associated with values under the normal curve.

nodes.label: Distinguishing between categorical nominal and ordinal data
nodes.title: Classifying categorical data into nominal (no inherent order) and ordinal (with a meaningful order) types.

nodes.label: Distinguishing between numerical discrete and continuous data
nodes.title: Classifying numerical data as discrete (countable values) or continuous (any value within an interval).

nodes.label: Population and sample concepts
nodes.title: Understanding the difference between the entire group being studied (population) and a subset selected for analysis (sample).

nodes.label: Simple random sampling
nodes.title: Selecting a sample from a population such that every member has an equal chance of being chosen.

nodes.label: Stratified sampling
nodes.title: Dividing the population into subgroups (strata) and randomly sampling from each to ensure representation.

nodes.label: Cluster sampling
nodes.title: Dividing the population into clusters and randomly selecting entire clusters for the sample.

nodes.label: Quota sampling
nodes.title: Selecting a sample that reflects certain characteristics of the population by filling quotas for those characteristics.

nodes.label: Formulating statistical questions
nodes.title: Creating clear, answerable questions that can be addressed using data analysis.

nodes.label: Collecting data from various sources
nodes.title: Gathering data through experiments, surveys, observational studies, or secondary sources such as the internet.

nodes.title: Displaying proportions of categories as slices of a circle to show relative frequencies.

nodes.label: Using bar charts for categorical data
nodes.title: Representing categorical data with rectangular bars whose lengths are proportional to the category frequencies.

nodes.title: Displaying data points along a number line to show frequency of values.

nodes.label: Using histograms with equal intervals
nodes.title: Representing numerical data by grouping values into equal-width intervals and displaying frequencies as bars.

nodes.title: Organizing numerical data to show distribution while retaining original data values.

nodes.title: Displaying two related data sets side by side to compare their distributions.

nodes.label: Using scatterplots to determine relationships between variables
nodes.title: Plotting paired data points to visualize potential correlations or associations between two variables.

nodes.label: Correlation coefficient as measure of linear relationship
nodes.title: A numerical value between -1 and +1 that quantifies the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

nodes.label: Matching correlation coefficient values to scatterplots
nodes.title: Interpreting scatterplots to estimate the correlation coefficient and understand the strength of association.

nodes.label: Understanding that correlation does not imply causality
nodes.title: Recognizing that a statistical association between variables does not necessarily mean one causes the other.

nodes.label: Measures of variability: range
nodes.title: The difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set.

nodes.label: Measures of variability: interquartile range (IQR)
nodes.title: The difference between the third quartile (Q3) and first quartile (Q1), representing the spread of the middle 50% of data.

nodes.title: Dividing ordered data into four equal parts to identify Q1, median (Q2), and Q3.

nodes.title: Measuring the average amount by which data values deviate from the mean, indicating spread or variability.

nodes.title: Identifying data points that are significantly different from the majority of the data, often using IQR or standard deviation criteria.

edges.title: The double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A = cos²A – sin²A) directly uses the squares of sine and cosine, which are related by the Pythagorean identity.
Expressing cos²A in terms of cos 2A relies on the Pythagorean identity to relate sine squared and cosine squared.
Expressing sin²A in terms of cos 2A uses the Pythagorean identity to connect sine squared and cosine squared.

Selecting r objects from n distinct objects requires understanding arrangements of r objects before considering unordered selections (combinations).
Computing binomial coefficients is based on counting the number of combinations of r objects from n distinct objects.
Understanding sample spaces is necessary to apply the principle of calculating probability as the ratio of favorable outcomes to total outcomes.
Set theory concepts underpin the use of Venn diagrams to represent and reason about probability rules involving unions, intersections, and exclusivity.
Understanding probability rules visually via Venn diagrams precedes formalizing these rules using algebraic formulae.
Solving problems on Bernoulli trials requires first understanding the concept and structure of Bernoulli trials.
Calculating the probability of the kth success on the nth trial builds on the ability to solve general Bernoulli trial probability problems.
Simulations help students understand variability, which is foundational for constructing sampling distributions and making inferences about the mean.
Understanding populations and samples is necessary before evaluating how conclusions from samples can be generalized to populations.
Knowledge of populations and samples supports working with and classifying different types of data collected from samples.
Formulating clear statistical questions guides the selection of appropriate data collection methods.
Understanding data collection methods precedes selecting representative samples from populations.
After selecting samples, students learn why representativeness is critical to avoid bias in statistical conclusions.
Sample selection knowledge is essential for designing effective data collection plans.
Understanding representativeness leads to awareness of biases, limitations, and ethical considerations in studies.
Recognising biases and limitations motivates understanding of randomisation and control groups to improve study validity.
Comparing data sets graphically prepares students to analyze relationships between variables via scatterplots.
Understanding scatterplots enables students to interpret correlation coefficients as measures of linear association.
After learning about correlation, students are taught the important distinction that correlation does not imply causation.
Basic summary statistics precede learning more advanced measures of variability such as standard deviation and IQR.
Understanding variability measures helps identify data points that deviate significantly, i.e., outliers.
Calculating correlation supports using the line of best fit to make predictions about data relationships.
Drawing the line of best fit visually is a precursor to using it for predictive purposes.
Interpreting data visualizations is necessary before connecting findings back to the original statistical question.
Describing variability and making inferences supports understanding the impact of sampling variability on conclusions.
